case_vignette: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his parents due to worsening cough, fever, and difficulty breathing in the past 2 days. Physical exam reveals a barking cough and use of accessory muscles for breathing. After a full clinical workup, he is diagnosed with an upper respiratory infection caused by a parainfluenza virus.
question: Which  findings in the clinical workup of this patient supported the diagnosis?
correct_ans: chest radiograph showing narrowing of upper trachea and subglottis

Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms, I would like to consider the possibility of asthma as a possible cause for your cough and difficulty breathing. Asthma is a common respiratory condition that can cause wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath.

I would like to perform a spirometry test to measure your lung function and determine if you have any airway obstruction. This can help us to confirm the diagnosis of asthma and determine the best course of treatment.

I don't know if there is asthma in my family and I don't know what might make my symptoms worse, but I'm okay with doing the spirometry test if it helps figure out what's wrong.

Great, the spirometry test will be very helpful in determining the cause of your symptoms. I will explain the test to you and answer any questions you may have before we begin.

During the test, you will be asked to breathe into a device called a spirometer, which measures the volume of air you can exhale from your lungs. The test is simple and painless, and it will take about 15-20 minutes to complete.

Based on the results of the spirometry test, we can determine if you have any airway obstruction or restriction, which can be indicative of asthma or other respiratory conditions. We may also perform other tests, such as a methacholine challenge, to further evaluate your lung function and diagnose the cause of your symptoms.

Once we have a confirmed diagnosis, we can develop a treatment plan to help manage your symptoms and improve your lung function. This may include medications, such as inhaled corticosteroids or bronchodilators, lifestyle changes, and other interventions as needed.
